channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Briefing: Brexit Live Updates: U.K. Cabinet Deciding Fate of Draft Deal
item.media:description: Even if the British cabinet approves the Brexit draft, the deal needs the approval of the British Parliament, which is far from a certainty.
item.description: With Britain’s departure from the European Union less than five months away, Prime Minister Theresa May faces the first true test of whether she can avoid a “no-deal” Brexit.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: First Rohingya Are to Be Returned to Myanmar Killing Grounds
item.media:description: A Rohingya refugee in the Kutupalong camp in Bangladesh in June. About 2,200 Rohingya Muslims who fled violence in Myanmar last year are set to be repatriated on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: More than 2,000 Rohingya Muslim refugees are set for repatriation from neighboring Bangladesh, many of them unwillingly. The United Nations calls it a “clear violation” of international principles.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel’s Hawkish Defense Minister Resigns and Calls for Early Elections
item.media:description: Avigdor Lieberman, center, visiting a crossing with the Gaza Strip in July. It was not immediately clear on Wednesday who would replace him.
item.description: Avigdor Lieberman accused the Netanyahu government of being soft on the unrest in Gaza, calling a cease-fire with Hamas a “capitulation to terror.”
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Behind a Saudi Prince’s Rise, Two Loyal Enforcers
item.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, right, pictured with Saad Hariri, the prime minister-designate of Lebanon, in Riyadh last month. The Saudis briefly kidnapped Mr. Hariri last year.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: The killing of Jamal Khashoggi has focused attention on two aides to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who have played key roles in his aggressive acts.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: France Says Trump’s Twitter Attack Lacks ‘Common Decency’
item.media:description: President Trump met with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris last week.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: A barrage of scathing tweets aimed at the French president, Emmanuel Macron, landed on the third anniversary of the Paris terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: New Questions Swirl Over Boeing on Updated 737 Model That Crashed
item.media:description: Indonesian investigators inspecting wreckage recovered from Lion Air Flight 610 at the Tanjung Priok port in Jakarta this month.
item.description: The airplane manufacturer did not provide airlines and pilots with full information about a new emergency system on the plane.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH, HIROKO TABUCHI, JAMES GLANZ and ZACH WICHTER

item.title: Another Twist in Sri Lanka: Parliament Votes Rajapaksa Out
item.media:description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, seated, the former Sri Lankan prime minister, was able to organize lawmakers on Wednesday against the appointment of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa to replace him.
item.description: Lawmakers passed a raucous no-confidence vote against former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, saying he must step down as prime minister. Now all eyes are on the president who appointed him.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: 3 Days Stranded in Siberia? Flight Delays Don’t Come Much Worse Than This
item.media:description: Air France planes at an airport near Paris. Flight 116 bound for Shanghai was diverted to the city of Irkutsk, about 3,000 miles east of Moscow, after an acrid smell and light smoke wafted through the cabin.
item.description: Passengers on an Air France plane that was forced to land at Irkutsk airport in Russia endured a nightmare stay after a replacement plane also developed a fault.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: A Battle in Gaza Neither Side Wanted Ends Quickly
item.media:description: A home in Gaza was one of dozens destroyed in the 24-hour battle. This house was close to Al Aqsa television, a Hamas-owned station that Israel bombed on Monday.
item.description: A fight that began with a botched Israeli raid drew intense fire but few deaths as both sides tried to limit casualties. By Tuesday, it was over.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: U.K. Ad Highlighting Plight of Orangutans Is Deemed Too ‘Political’ to Air
item.description: The animated commercial for the food retailer Iceland, featuring a baby orangutan, noted that the palm oil industry contributed to the destruction of rain forests and habitats.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: What Makes Someone French? If You Live in France, We Want to Hear From You
item.description: As the divide over French identity deepens, tell us how your views have evolved.
item.dc:creator: LARA TAKENAGA

item.title: At War: A Letter to the Army: Don’t Punish the Man Who Led the Mission That Killed My Son
item.media:description: Henry Black touches the name plate of his son Staff Sgt. Bryan Black on a memorial wall at Fort Bragg in May 2018.
item.media:credit: Andrew Craft/The Fayetteville Observer, via Associated Press
item.description: The father of one of the American soldiers killed in Niger last year writes a letter of support for the Army captain who led the fateful mission.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Australians Declare Existential Crisis Over Onion Placement
item.media:description: Sausages sit on a barbecue as voters queue at a voting station in the Sydney suburb of Double Bay in 2016.
item.description: Bunnings, a chain of hardware stores, upended tradition and suggested people put onions on the bottom and not the top of their sausages. Australians were not impressed.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: Brexit Could Leave Wedding Bouquets Stuck at the Border
item.media:description: More than a third of the global flower trade flows through the Aalsmeer marketplace in the Netherlands.
item.media:credit: Andrew Urwin for The New York Times
item.description: From greenhouses in Kenya to auction houses in the Netherlands to florists in London, the shipment of flowers highlights Brexit’s potential disruption to trade.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: California Wildfires, Amazon, Midterms: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: What to Know About Gaza’s Latest Flare-Up
item.media:description: A view of the city of Ashkelon in southern Israel as the missile defense system responds to rocket fire on Monday.
item.description: The latest flare-up in the slow burning conflict between Israel and Hamas highlights a larger conflict. Here's what to know.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: U.N. Rights Officials Criticize China Over Muslim Internments
item.media:description: Uighur Muslims demonstrated in Brussels in September against China’s mass detention of Uighurs in the western region of Xinjiang.
item.description: Human rights officials and experts condemned regulations on Chinese re-education camps as a violation of international law and criminalized basic rights.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Merkel Joins Macron in Calling for a European Army ‘One Day’
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany speaking at the European Parliament on Tuesday in Strasbourg, France.
item.description: After another strained meeting with President Trump, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany calls for a European army to reduce dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sri Lanka’s President Finally Checked: Court Rules to Bring Back Parliament
item.media:description: Supporters of Sri Lanka’s ousted prime minister Ranil Wickremesinghe celebrated in Colombo on Tuesday after the Supreme Court suspended the dissolution of parliament.
item.description: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court issued an interim order against the president, preventing him from firing the Parliament.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Suspect Who Looks Like Ross From ‘Friends’ Is Arrested
item.media:description: Ross? Is that you? The police photo of the suspect.
item.description: It was a routine case save for one detail: The accused thief bore an uncanny resemblance to the actor David Schwimmer.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Papua New Guinea Is Rich in Resources but Poor in Health
item.media:description: A mother and her baby at a health clinic where polio vaccines were administered to children in Lae, Papua New Guinea, in July. Vaccination rates are down to 30 percent in some parts of the country.
item.description: The Pacific nation hoped that hosting the APEC summit meeting would elevate its international profile, but a national health crisis threatens to overshadow it.
item.dc:creator: JO CHANDLER

item.title: After Grief and Defiance, Arts Help Process 2015 Paris Attacks
item.media:description: A ceremony Tuesday outside the town hall of the 11th arrondissement in Paris commemorates the third anniversary of the Nov. 13 attacks.
item.description: Three years after the terrorist attacks that killed 130 people, films, novels and memoirs allow survivors and others make some sense of what happened.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: The First Thanksgiving
item.media:description: Preparing for her first Thanksgiving dinner, Mayada Anjari roasted a turkey in her kitchen in Jersey City.
item.media:credit: Christina Holmes for The New York Times
item.description: Recently arrived refugees in the United States prepare to cook the most American of feasts.
item.dc:creator: JULIA MOSKIN

item.title: Britain and E.U. Agree on a Draft Deal for Brexit
item.media:description: Protesters in London last month seeking a people’s vote on the final Brexit deal. The terms of Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union have divided Britons and the governing Conservative Party.
item.description: The agreement is being reviewed by Conservative cabinet members before a full meeting on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: In Prison for 16 Years, and Still Waiting for a Verdict
item.media:description: Daniel García in the Barrientos state prison, just outside Mexico City, where he has been held for more than 16 years without a verdict.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: The case of Daniel García, charged with murder, exemplifies many flaws of Mexico’s old justice system. An overhaul of the system has helped others — but not him.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Erdogan Presses for Answers From Saudi Prince in Khashoggi Killing
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman, had failed to expose the truth about the disappearance and death of Mr. Khashoggi.
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.description: The Turkish president expressed frustration to reporters, saying the de facto leader of Saudi Arabia had done nothing to expose the truth about the dissident’s death.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: U.N.’s Expert on ‘Extreme Poverty’ Is Investigating Britain. Why?
item.media:description: Without food banks like this one in Newcastle, England, “we wouldn’t be able to survive,” says a British woman.
item.media:credit: José Sarmento Matos for The New York Times
item.description: Normally, Philip Alston spends his time in the developing world. But the United Nations expert on extreme poverty sees Britain as the ideal test case of the effects of “self-imposed austerity.”
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Australia’s Prime Minister ‘Surprised’ by State’s Secret Deal With China
item.media:description: Australia's prime minister, Scott Morrison, said it was not “cooperative or helpful” for the state of Victoria to sign an agreement with China without his government’s knowledge.
item.description: The state of Victoria signed on with China’s Belt and Road initiative at a time when intelligence officials are concerned about Beijing’s influence.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY and VICKY XIUZHONG XU

item.title: California Wildfires, Elections, Nafta: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: ‘Tell Your Boss’: Recording Is Seen to Link Saudi Crown Prince More Strongly to Khashoggi Killing
item.media:description: A commemoration for the journalist Jamal Khashoggi on Sunday in Istanbul.
item.description: A Saudi operative’s comments to a royal aide after the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi is among the strongest evidence yet tying Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to his death.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES, ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: My Moments With Stan
item.description: In a tribute comic, Brian Michael Bendis reflects on the first time he met Stan Lee and how Mr. Lee inspired him in his two-decade career at Marvel Comics.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN MICHAEL BENDIS, BILL WALKO and HOWIE NOEL

item.title: A ‘Time Capsule’ for Scientists, Courtesy of Peter the Great
item.media:description: A pair of Amur tigers, a gift from a German merchant to Czar Alexander II, on display at the Zoological Museum in St. Petersburg.
item.media:credit: Photographs by James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A Russian zoological museum filled with centuries-old specimens finds renewed relevance in the age of genetics.
item.dc:creator: JAMES HILL
item.category: Zoological Museum of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences

item.title: ‘Patriotism Is the Exact Opposite of Nationalism,’ Macron Says
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke about the dangers of nationalism in a speech commemorating the anniversary of the armistice that ended World War I. In attendance was President Trump, who recently called himself a nationalist.

item.title: Merkel Antagonist Quits Party Post but Stays On as Interior Minister
item.media:description: Horst Seehofer, the German interior minister, in Bautzen, Germany, on Monday. Mr. Seehofer will step down from his post as chairman of the conservative Christian Social Union party in January.
item.description: Horst Seehofer’s announcement that he would step down as head of his Bavarian conservative party comes after a similar decision by Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Cost of Botched Gaza Spy Mission? Israel’s Back on Brink of War
item.media:description: A bus burns in Israel on Monday after it was hit in a rocket and mortar attack from the Gaza Strip.
item.description: Israel and Hamas exchanged intense fire after a covert Israeli operation went awry. The resulting fighting threatened to scuttle peace talks.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Stimulus Plan or Populist Giveaway? Italy’s Budget Sets Up Clash With E.U.
item.media:description: A market in Naples, Italy. The anti-establishment Five Star Movement is looking to rally support in the relatively poor south of the country with a welfare program estimated to cost around $9 billion.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: How best to invigorate the country’s economy has reanimated a wrenching debate in Europe about whether it is better to spend or cut in the face of stagnation.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: China, After Outcry, Reinstates Ban on Rhino and Tiger Parts in Medicine
item.media:description: A market for traditional medicine ingredients in Guangzhou, China. While doctors generally prefer herbal remedies, there is a small but lucrative trade in rhino and tiger parts.
item.description: The State Council said in a rare concession that it had decided to postpone an order to undo a 25-year prohibition on the trade.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Taliban Slaughter Elite Afghan Troops, and a ‘Safe’ District Is Falling
item.media:description: The bodies of 20 commandos were lined up outside the governor’s office in Sang-e-Masha, Afghanistan, on Sunday. Their company was almost entirely destroyed fighting the Taliban.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: Times journalists traveled to the site of a Taliban assault. Instead of a fierce stand by government commandos, they found a massacre of those American-trained troops.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: U.S. Navy Carrier Suffers Second Aircraft Crash in Weeks
item.media:description: Two aircraft assigned to the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan have crashed in recent months, including an F/A 18 Hornet on Monday.
item.media:credit: Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Kaila V. Peters/United States Navy, via Associated Press
item.description: An F/A-18 Super Hornet, assigned to the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan, on Monday crashed into the sea northeast of the Philippines. The two aviators inside the plane were rescued.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Coming to Papua New Guinea: World Leaders (and 40 Maseratis)
item.media:description: A new road in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, linking Parliament to venues for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting being held this week. The country is by far the poorest of APEC’s 21 member economies.
item.media:credit: Ben C. Solomon/The New York Times
item.description: The island nation, the poorest member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation regional forum, has spent lavishly as host of the group’s annual summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Portugal Dispatch: This Town Once Feared the 10-Story Waves. Then the Extreme Surfers Showed Up.
item.media:description: For centuries, Nazaré was a traditional seaside town where Portuguese fishermen taught their children to avoid the huge waves that crashed against the nearby cliffs.
item.media:credit: Ana Brigida for The New York Times
item.description: The residents of Nazaré used to think the immense waves that broke against town’s cliffs were deadly to any who braved them. Today, those same waves have made the town a surfers’ mecca.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Australian Woman Accused of Spiking Strawberries With Needles
item.media:description: The strawberry contamination scare led Australian supermarkets to post warning notices. Some markets stopped stocking the fruit entirely.
item.description: The tampering fueled a nationwide panic that severely hurt the industry, prompted copycat incidents and led some stores to stop stocking the fruit.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Deadly Gaza Raid by Israel Threatens Nascent Cease-Fire
item.media:description: A destroyed building on Monday in Khan Yunis, in southern Gaza, after an Israeli airstrike over the weekend.
item.description: A covert mission apparently went awry on Sunday, leaving an Israeli lieutenant colonel and at least seven Palestinians dead and setting off a flurry of rocket fire and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Canada’s Message to Teenagers: Marijuana Is Legal Now. Please Don’t Smoke It.
item.media:description: Jenny Hanley, seated in front, and her daughter Shelby Hanley, 17, left, with Kyle Johnston, 16, center, and Jared Kaye, 19, right, who live with Ms. Hanley on her family farm.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: Canadian teenagers use more marijuana than youths anywhere else in the world. The government hopes legalization will change that.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Poland’s Leaders March With Far-Right Groups on Independence Day
item.media:description: A banner reading “Independence March — Death to the enemies of the homeland” in Warsaw on Sunday.
item.description: The president said the 100th anniversary of Polish independence was “for everyone.” The march included the far right and omitted opposition leaders.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: In China, Desperate Patients Smuggle Drugs. Or Make Their Own.
item.media:description: Zhang Zhejun, a salesmen in Hebei, China, made his own drugs from ingredients purchased online to give to his mother, who suffered from lung cancer.
item.description: Despite health insurance, terminally ill patients have to hunt around the world and on the internet for ways to stay alive.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: France’s Mayors, Feeling the Pinch, Lead a Quiet Rebellion and Quit
item.media:description: “What’s the use of giving it your all, when the results just don’t come anymore,” said Louis Gentilhomme, the ex-mayor of Saint-Seine-sur-Vingeanne, who quit earlier this year.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: More than 150 rural mayors have left this year, saying they feel abandoned by the state in the face of shrinking revenues, declining populations and reforms initiated by President Emmanuel Macron.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Saudis Close to Crown Prince Discussed Killing Other Enemies a Year Before Khashoggi’s Death
item.media:description: Top Saudi officials considered using private companies to assassinate political enemies at a time when Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was consolidating power.
item.description: During discussions in Riyadh in 2017, Saudi intelligence officials discussed hiring private companies to kill the head of Iran’s Quds force and other Iranian operatives.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, RONEN BERGMAN and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
